description: From Middle English idel, ydel, from Old English īdel, from Proto-West Germanic *īdal, from Proto-Germanic *īdalaz. Cognate with Dutch ijdel (“vain, meaningless”), German Low German iedel (“vain, idle”), German eitel (“vain, conceited”), and possibly Old Norse illr ("bad"; > English ill).

adjectives.description: idle (comparative more idle, superlative most idle)

entries.meaning: Not being used appropriately; not occupied; (of time) with no, no important, or not much activity.
examples: My computer hibernates after it has been idle for 30 minutes.

entries.meaning: Not engaged in any occupation or employment; unemployed; inactive; doing nothing in particular.
Averse to work, labor or employment; lazy; slothful.
Of no importance; useless; worthless; vain; trifling; thoughtless; silly.
examples: an idle story;  idle talk;  idle rumor

description: From Middle English idelen, from Old English īdlian, from Proto-West Germanic *īdalēn. Cognate with German eiteln (“to make empty, free up”).

verbs.description: idle (third-person singular simple present idles, present participle idling, simple past and past participle idled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To spend in idleness; to waste; to consume.
(intransitive) To lose or spend time doing nothing, or without being employed in business.
examples: to idle in an IRC channel

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of an engine: to run at a slow speed, or out of gear; to tick over.

description: From Middle English idel, ydel, from Old English īdel (“idleness”), from teh adjective (see above).

entries.meaning: The state of idling, of being idle.
(mechanical engineering) The lowest selectable thrust or power setting of an engine.
